wikipedia_page.main:
Victor Rousseau Emanuel, originally Avigdor Rousseau Emanuel (January 1879, England - 6 April 1960, Tarrytown) was a British writer who wrote novels, newspaper series, science fiction and pulp fiction works. He was active in Great Britain and the United States during the first half of the 20th century. 
During the first 20 years of his career, Emanuel wrote predominantly under the pen names Victor Rousseau, H. M. Egbert, and V. R. Emanuel.  In the 1930s, he only created pulp fiction under his own name. He wrote racy stories under the pen name Lew Merrill.

response: *  Article, by Isidore Singer & Victor Rousseau Emanuel

All novels were published under the house name of John Grange (a reference, perhaps, to legendary football players Jim Thorpe and Red Grange, the former a famous Native American athlete).  The first three novels are known to have been written by Victor Rousseau Emanuel.  From the sixteenth novel to the end, they were written by Robert Leslie Bellem and W.T. Ballard.  The authorship of the others is unknown, but is suspected to be Victor Rousseau Emanuel.
* Victor Rousseau Emanuel publishes The Messiah of the Cylinder.
